      • saturate

        public static double saturate(double val)
        Ensures val is in the range of 0.0 to 1.0. If val is greater than 1.0, this will return 1.0. If val is less than 0.0, this will return 0.0. Otherwise, val is returned unchanged.
        Parameters:
        val - The value to saturate
        Returns:
        val, saturated between 0.0 and 1.0.

      • clamp

        public static int clamp(int val,
        int min,
        int max)
        Ensures val is in the range of min to max. If val is greater than max, this will return max. If val is less than min, this will return min. Otherwise, val is returned unchanged.
        Parameters:
        val - The value to calmp.
        min - The smallest value of the result.
        max - The largerst value of the result.
        Returns:
        val, clamped between min and max.

      • clamp

        Parameters:

        min - The smallest value of the result.
        max - The largerst value of the result.
        Returns:

      • floorMod

        public static int floorMod(int num,
           int den)
        A flooring modulus operator. Works similarly to the % operator, except this rounds towards negative infinity rather than towards 0.

        For example:
        -7 % 3 = -2; floorMod(-7, 3) = 2
        -6 % 3 = -0; floorMod(-6, 3) = 0
        -5 % 3 = -2; floorMod(-5, 3) = 1
        -4 % 3 = -1; floorMod(-4, 3) = 2
        -3 % 3 = -0; floorMod(-3, 3) = 0
        -2 % 3 = -2; floorMod(-2, 3) = 1
        -1 % 3 = -1; floorMod(-1, 3) = 2
        0 % 3 = 0; floorMod(0, 3) = 0
        1 % 3 = 1; floorMod(1, 3) = 1
        2 % 3 = 2; floorMod(2, 3) = 2
        3 % 3 = 0; floorMod(3, 3) = 0
        4 % 3 = 1; floorMod(4, 3) = 1

        Parameters:
        num - The numerator of the modulus operator.
        den - The denominator of the modulus operator.
        Returns:
        num % den, rounded towards negative infinity.

      • floorMod

        public static double floorMod(double num,
              double den)
        A flooring modulus operator. Works similarly to the % operator, except this rounds towards negative infinity rather than towards 0.

        For example:
        -7 % 3 = -2; floorMod(-7, 3) = 2
        -6 % 3 = -0; floorMod(-6, 3) = 0
        -5 % 3 = -2; floorMod(-5, 3) = 1
        -4 % 3 = -1; floorMod(-4, 3) = 2
        -3 % 3 = -0; floorMod(-3, 3) = 0
        -2 % 3 = -2; floorMod(-2, 3) = 1
        -1 % 3 = -1; floorMod(-1, 3) = 2
        0 % 3 = 0; floorMod(0, 3) = 0
        1 % 3 = 1; floorMod(1, 3) = 1
        2 % 3 = 2; floorMod(2, 3) = 2
        3 % 3 = 0; floorMod(3, 3) = 0
        4 % 3 = 1; floorMod(4, 3) = 1

        Parameters:
        num - The numerator of the modulus operator.
        den - The denominator of the modulus operator.
        Returns:
        num % den, rounded towards negative infinity.

      • boundsAssert

        public static void boundsAssert(int index,
                int min,
                int max)
        Ensures that index >= min and index <= max.
        Parameters:
        index - The index of interest.
        min - The smallest valid value of index.
        max - The largest valid value of index.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IndexOutOfBoundsException - If index is not within the range of (min, max ).

      • wrapString

        public static java.lang.String wrapString(java.lang.String str,
                          double maxLength)
        Word wraps a string. Inserts newline characters after some complete words to keep each line as close to maxLength as possible without exceeding it. No words are split in this manner. If a word is longer than maxLength, then the word is left intact and that line shall exceed maxLength.
        Parameters:
        str - The string to word wrap.
        maxLength - The maximum length one line of string can contain.
        Returns:
        A new String with word wrapping.
